raw_text:
Ericsson sees earnings improve
 
 Telecoms equipment supplier Ericsson has posted a rise in fourth quarter profits thanks to clients like Deutsche Telekom upgrade their networks.
 
 Operating profit in the three months to 31 December was 9.5bn kronor (£722m; $1.3bn) against 6.3bn kronor last year. Shares tumbled, however, as the company reported a profit margin of 45.6%, less than the 47.3% forecast by analysts and down from 47.1% in the third quarter. Ericsson shares dropped 5.9% to 20.7 kronor in early trading on Thursday. However, the company remained optimistic about its earnings outlook after sales in the fourth quarter rose 9% to 39.4bn kronor. "Long-term growth drivers of the industry remain solid," Ericsson said in a statement.
 
 Chief executive Carl-Henric Svanberg explained that about "27% of the world's population now has access to mobile communications". "This is exciting for a company with a vision of an all-communicating world," he added. Mr Svanberg, however, warned that the extra demand that had driven 2004 sales had already dissipated and it was "business as usual". He added that sales in the first three months of 2005 would be subject to "normal seasonality". For the whole of 2004, Ericsson returned a net profit of 19bn kronor, compared with a loss of 10.8bn kronor in 2003. Sales climbed to 131.9 billion kronor from 117.7bn kronor in 2003.
llama3.2:1b: Ericsson reported a rise in profits for the fourth quarter due to clients upgrading their networks, but shares dropped due to lower profit margins and forecasted earnings.
The company's sales increased by 9% to $1.3 billion.
Shares fell by 5.9% after the report.
Despite this, Ericsson remains optimistic about its earnings outlook and growth drivers remain solid in the long term.
llama3.2:3b: Ericsson's fourth quarter profits rose 50% to 9.5bn kronor due to clients upgrading their networks.
Shares dropped 5.9% despite a 9% increase in sales, which reached 39.4bn kronor.
The company remains optimistic about its earnings outlook.
gemma2:2b: Ericsson's fourth quarter profits increased thanks to client network upgrades, reaching 9.5 billion kronor.
However, the company saw a lower profit margin than analysts expected and share prices fell.
Despite this, Ericsson remains optimistic about future earnings due to strong industry growth.
The CEO noted that mobile phone access has expanded globally and predicted that sales will remain steady in 2005 despite initial gains from high demand.
Overall, Ericsson's net profit for 2004 increased significantly compared to the previous year.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Ericsson reported strong fourth quarter profits, marking an improvement compared to the same period a year ago.
While its operating profit decreased slightly from 6.3 billion Kronor last year, analysts forecast a rise of 45.6%.
The company has continued to make progress in its earnings outlook, with sales expected to grow by 9% and total revenues reaching 39.4 billion Kronor by the end of 2005.
The chief executive highlighted that more than two-thirds of the world's population now has access to mobile communications, a positive development for Ericsson.
He also mentioned a business-as-usual approach in anticipation of rising demand from the first three months of the fiscal year.
Despite this, sales in the first quarter were reported as normal seasonality.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Telecommunications equipment supplier Ericsson reports improved earnings for the fourth quarter, driven by client upgrades and optimistic outlook despite a slight margin decline.
Shares experience volatility following the announcement of a rise in profits, with sales and earnings expected to remain steady for the remainder of the year.
qwen2.5:3b: Ericsson reports a significant increase in fourth quarter profits driven by client upgrades, reaching 9.5bn kronor (€722m; $1.3bn) compared to last year's 6.3bn kronor.
Despite a profit margin of 45.6% lower than analysts' forecast and down from 47.1%, shares dropped by 5.9%.
Sales in the quarter rose 9% to 39.4bn kronor.
The company remains optimistic about future growth, attributing it to solid industry drivers, despite expecting normal seasonality for 2005 sales.
CEO Carl-Henric Svanberg emphasized that demand-driven sales from 2004 have dissipated and the focus is on maintaining business as usual.
Overall net profit for 2004 was 19bn kronor versus a loss of 10.8bn in 2003, with total sales increasing to 131.9bn kronor from 117.7bn in the same period.
opencoder:1.5b: "Telecoms equipment supplier Ericsson has posted a rise in fourth quarter profits thanks to clients like Deutsche Telekom upgrade their networks.
The company reported a profit margin of 45.6%, less than the 47.3% forecast by analysts and down from 47.1% in the third quarter.
The company remained optimistic about its earnings outlook after sales in the fourth quarter rose 9% to 39.4bn kronor."
smollm:1.7b: Ericsson has posted a rise in fourth quarter profits thanks to clients like Deutsche Telekom upgrade their networks.
Operating profit in the three months to 31 December was 9.5bn kronor (£722m; $1.3bn) against 6.3bn kronor last year.
Shares tumbled, however, as the company reported a profit margin of 45.6%, less than the 47.1% forecast by analysts and down from 47.1% in the third quarter.
Ericsson shares dropped 5.9% to 20.7 kronor on early trading Thursday.
However, the company remained optimistic about its earnings outlook after sales in the fourth quarter rose 9% to 39.4bn kronor.
"Long-term growth drivers of the industry remain solid," Ericsson said in a statement.
Ericsson's operating profit for the three months ended December 31 was 9.5bn kronor, up from 6.3bn kronor last year and down by 45.6% from its forecast.
The company reported a net profit of 19bn kronor in the same period last year, compared with 10.8bn kronor in 2003.
Sales climbed to 131.9 billion kronor from 117.7bn kronor in 2003.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Ericsson reported improved fourth-quarter profits after a 9% increase in sales due to Deutsche Telekom upgrading its networks.
Despite a profit margin dip to 45.6%, Ericsson maintained optimistic growth outlook for 2005 and saw a net profit of $722 million compared to a loss in 2003, with sales rising to $131.9 billion.
tinyllama:1.1b: Ericsson has reported a rise in earnings for the fourth quarter, thanks to clients such as Deutsche Telekom upgrading their networks.
The company also reported a drop in profit margin from 47.1% to 45.6%, but the company remains optimistic about its outlook despite sales dipping slightly compared to the third quarter.
Ericsson's CEO Carl-Henrik Svankberg emphasized that the world's population now has access to mobile communication, and this is "exciting for a company with a vision of an all-communicating world."
However, the extra demand in 2004 had dissipated, and Ericsson warned of "normal seasonality" in sales for the whole of 2005.
Sales reached 131.9 billion krone in 2004 compared with 117.7 billion krone in 2003.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Operating profit for the fourth quarter was 9.5 billion kronor, up by 8.4 billion kronor or 9.5 percent from the same period last year.
The company saw increased sales of 9 percent to 39.4 billion kronor, which was a significant increase from the third quarter's 27 percent growth rate.

Ericsson also reported that its earnings per share rose by 10.8 percent to 6.3 billion kronor in the same period as it increased its profit margin to 45.6 percent, which they attributed to lower costs and increased efficiency.

The CEO of Ericsson, Carl-Henric Svanberg, expressed optimism about the company's future growth opportunities, stating that "this is an exciting time for a company with a vision of an all-communicating world."
Sales in the first three months of 2005 would be subject to "normal seasonality" as compared to last year, and Ericsson anticipated generating around $1.3 billion in sales throughout the year.

In conclusion, Ericsson reported a rise in operating profit, an increase in sales, and an improvement in earnings per share from the fourth quarter of 2004, all of which indicate that the company continues to perform well despite the challenging business environment.
phi:2.7b: Ericsson reported an increase in profits due to network upgrades by clients like Deutsche Telekom, but its profit margin decreased slightly compared to the third quarter and analysts' expectations.
However, the company remains optimistic about its earnings outlook for the future.
Sales in the fourth quarter rose 9% to 39.4bn kronor, with 27% of the world's population having access to mobile communications.
The company warned that demand was dissipating and predicted normal seasonality for sales in the first three months of 2005.
Overall, Ericsson reported a net profit of 19bn kronor in 2004.
orca-mini:3b: Telecoms equipment supplier Ericsson reported a rise in fourth quarter profits thanks to clients like Deutsche Telekom upgrading their networks, but shares dropped as the company's profit margin fell and analysts forecasted lower earnings growth.
The company's chief executive said about "27% of the world's population now has access to mobile communications", which was exciting for a company with a vision of an all-communicating world.
However, sales in the first three months of 2005 would be subject to "normal seasonality" and earnings in the whole of 2004 had already dissipated.

stablelm-zephyr:3b: Ericsson reported a 9.5 billion kronor profit in Q4 2004, up from 6.3 billion kronor the previous year, due to clients like Deutsche Telekom upgrading their networks.
Shares dropped despite a 9% increase in sales to 39.4 billion kronor, as the company's profit margin was below forecasts.
Ericsson's CEO warned that extra demand in 2004 had dissipated and sales would be subject to normal seasonality in 2005.
The company expressed optimism about long-term growth drivers amid an increasing mobile communications access rate worldwide.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Ericsson reported a rise in fourth-quarter profits, with operating profit reaching 9.5bn kronor, up from 6.3bn kronor the previous year, driven by network upgrades from clients like Deutsche Telekom.
However, shares fell 5.9% as profit margins of 45.6% missed analyst expectations.
Despite this, Ericsson remained optimistic, citing a 9% increase in sales to 39.4bn kronor and strong long-term industry growth.
CEO Carl-Henric Svanberg highlighted that 27% of the global population now has mobile access but warned that the extra demand from 2004 had subsided.
Ericsson posted a net profit of 19bn kronor for 2004, reversing a 10.8bn kronor loss in 2003, with annual sales rising to 131.9bn kronor from 117.7bn kronor.
stablelm2:1.6b: Swedish electronics firm Ericsson has seen an improvement in Q4 earnings due to network upgrades by clients like Deutsche Telekom, despite a share decline.
Operating profit for Q4 was 9.5 billion krona ($1.3bn), up from last year's 6.3 billion krona, although the profit margin fell below expectations (6%).
Ericsson reported a 9% increase in sales to 4 billion krona.
CEO Carl-Heinic Svanberg said "business as usual" following higher demand and warns that it won.
For the whole of 2015, Ericsson returned a net profit of 9 billion krona ($1bn), up from a loss of 8.8 billion krona in 2014.
Sales rose to 9 billion krona from 7 billion krona in 2014.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Ericsson, a telecoms equipment supplier, reported a 5.9% drop in share price after announcing a 45.6% profit margin for Q4 2004, compared to the analysts' forecast of 47.3%.
Despite this, operating profit increased to 9.5 billion kronor from 6.3 billion kronor in Q4 2003.
Sales rose 9% to 39.4 billion kronor in Q4, with a year-on-year growth of 14.2%.
For the full year 2004, Ericsson posted a net profit of 19 billion kronor, reversing the 2003 loss of 10.8 billion kronor.
Chief Executive Carl-Henric Svanberg highlighted that 27% of the global population now has mobile access, emphasizing long-term industry growth drivers.
However, he cautioned that the surge in demand during 2004 had subsided, and sales in Q1 2005 would follow normal seasonal trends.
